phrases: Sophia Jackson is a 57-year-old female here for a surgical consult for melanoma of the inferior back.
Her dermatologist referred her after biopsying a 0.7 millimeter lesion on her inferior back, which was diagnosed as melanoma.
The lesion was noticed by her mother during a visit last month.
She had the biopsy on April 10th due to family history of melanoma (mother and maternal aunt).
She denies a personal history of atypical nevi and reports annual mole checks by her primary care provider.
Mother and maternal aunt both had melanoma.
Maternal grandfather had pancreatic cancer; no family history of breast or ovarian cancers.
Owns an auto repair shop.
Current smoker since teens, actively trying to quit.
No reported medical conditions; allergic to Augmentin.
Prior surgeries: cholecystectomy and appendectomy.
On the inferior back: 1 cm shave biopsy site with no residual pigmentation; no intrinsic or satellite lesions.
No axillary, cervical, or supraclavicular lymphadenopathy.
Soft, nontender lymph node in the groin (right side noted in pathology).
Shave biopsy of inferior back: malignant melanoma, invasive, superficial spreading.
Clark level 4, Breslow thickness 0.7 mm.
Radial growth phase present; no vertical growth, ulceration, or lymphatic invasion.
Peripheral margin positive, deep margin negative; stage 1.
Recommended ultrasound of the groin lymph node to rule out metastatic disease.
If ultrasound is normal, wide local excision with 1-2 cm margin is planned.
Primary closure preferred, but skin graft may be needed.
Emphasized sun avoidance, skin self-examination, and ABCDE mole surveillance.
Patient understands risks/benefits and consents to proceed.
Dermatologist’s photo showed an asymmetric black/brown nevus with irregular border.
Follow-up with dermatologist for ongoing surveillance is critical.
